82676741.review: This is a fairly open exploration game about searching planets for resources, and finding hidden secrets. Be warned that the controls are unusual, and that it provides minimal direction. You will likely feel lost at several points. Be careful about opting to use guides, as this may spoil some of the charm. However, if you are not highly interested in directing your own play, this game may not be right for you.

79638735.review:
This game features some really great art design, and interesting game play elements. If you like exploration and hoarding resources to expand your base, as well as researching technology to visit other planets, then you'll probably have a good time with this game.

There is one thing I have to say though... this is not a survival game. Why? Because there is no threat of death so long as you stand still. From the very first moment you start a game and land on the first planet surface, you are not in any danger. All you have to do is stand next to your landing pod and you will be supplied with endless oxygen and you'll never die. There's no hunger, no thirst, no actual requirement to move even one inch from where you started. You essentially have conquered the game without even doing anything.

48581456.review: The ultimate de-stress game! An absolute blast with friends and a terrific concept, glad to see it being further fleshed out and developed.

95630260.review:
Astroneer can in a way be described as the loneliest game out there (aside from No Man's Sky) - lonelier than Subnautica. If you're in single-player, you'll be all alone in the solar system. But there is an ever-present feeling of that there's something more - maybe even someone. There's a mystery to the game, and as the developers are constantly improving upon the game and adding new features, there may even be more of a mystery to it soon. 

I haven't reached the end of the game, playing around with the mechanics alone was entertaining (and distracting) enough for me. Now they've added automation, so there's even more to do, if exploring isn't all you burn for. The layout of the planets or types of planets will always be the same from session to session, so it's convenient that it has a lore and familiarity to it. I suspect the terrain of the planets themselves is proceduraly generated, as I can never remember exactly what cave is where, etc. 

Since the last time I played, they added some plants to Calidor and fixed some performance bugs on Glacio. Calidor now has some harmless plants, but they still scare me. The rule has always been "the more detail it has, the likelier it is to kill you."

All in all, I recommend it, but it's one of that games that you eventually might get tired off, and take a break from, only to return a few months later. It's also dangerously easy for hours to pass by without you noticing, so keep an eye out ;)

78830325.review: Fun, game, for all ages.  Son and I love it!

90082486.review:
1) ASTRONEER is fun, innovative, and original.
2) The Devs actively update and improve the base game, and demonstrate a real commitment to their work,
3) Replayability is high, as Special Events and Updates frequently give it that fresh look and feel.
4) Rebalancing since the early days has made it less grindy and M-U-C-H more fun to play & replay
5) it is a very good value for the hours you will spend enjoying it.

My review is based on years of playing through the game (2017-Present) - start to finish, over and over. When you have completed the game for the first time, you inevitably analyze what you did right, and what you did that was comically inefficient. And on the next replay, you find how easy it can be, to the point of eventually speed-running the whole thing. (I relate this initial struggle and ultimate cake walk to the first time I played Subnautica LOL. In Subnautica, I was afraid of my own shadow the moment it became dark my first time out, and insanely cautious. But with a couple of runs I could complete the entire game in a very short time). Well, there is nothing scary in ASTRONEER (aside from occasionally aggressive flora), and it is easy to master & enjoy.

I whole-heartedly Recommend ASTRONEER, whether playing Solo or Co-op - You will have a great time.... over and over. I know I have - Cheers

54668871.review: This game is meditative. The music and art pulls you into a zen state, and then for the next few hours you're just chilling with no sense of time.

83240355.review:
This really is just the most satisfying and relaxing game I've ever played. It's super easy to understand and get to grips with in general, but the wiki does help for keeping track of certain recipes or whatever. There are occasional bugs you come across, but nothing too mental.

One thing I really appreciate in this game is that you can unlock cosmetics through getting achievements. It's something I've always really appreciated in games but thinking about it, the last game I remember enjoying this feature in is Halo 3, so if you're like me and you love stuff like that, it'll only add to the enjoyment you get from this game.
The multiplayer is seamless (maybe a little too seamless as you're not notified in any way if a friend hops in your game) and is more buggy than single player, but again, not too crazy, and understandable as the game is still seemingly in an early state.

It's really quickly become one of my favourite games, and I'm jealous of kids that'll get to grow up playing this, because this would have been 1000% my jam if it was around when I was little. There's things you come across in this game that are seriously awe-striking and I really recommend just experiencing the game for yourself before watching anything on it, because it's like nothing I've ever played before.

9.5/10 minor bugs, incredible game.

102479748.review:
Very chill game, basic base building and resource crafting, and exploration.  No rush, no stress, nice sound track and audio design.
Great for clearing the stress while you listen to some tunes.

106368151.review:
This game is amazing. On the surface it is a simple little game where you run around and try to keep you space man from suffocating all while feeling relaxed and unbothered. It has a very fun, simplistic inventory system that I have very much enjoyed.

Once you are past the surface of the game, you realize there are a  lot of very well thought out systems for automation and travel that you can use to your advantage. You don't have to use any of them to enjoy the game but I think they add another level of complexity that is rewarding to figure out.

All in all, this game is a wonderfully crafted open world survival game gives you as much as you put into it and let's you work at your own pace towards your goals or the game's. 20 out of 10 would absolutely recommend!

100867037.review:
This game is exceptionally great at being itself, which may be a weird way to put it, but it I find it hard to compare it to something because it is so unique. It's a game that I would have never thought of buying because I didn't even know I wanted what it had to offer. I've played "survival crafting" before, but that is somehow a too narrow label for this game, even though it is entirely accurate.

Astroneer is an open world survival game set in a predefined solar system with procedurally-generated planets and a fixed story line. Still, it offers surprising replay value and caters to both casual and more "exploitative" gameplay styles. Being able to leave a persistent impact on a system-wide scale is an empowering experience. While its voxel-based terrain has a simplistic optic, I find it regularly offers inspiring vistas and immersive environments.

There are limits to how creative you can get, however, and perfectionists may find themselves relentlessly trolled by minor imperfections you can never quite get rid of. But you don't have to get bogged down in details - I once built a road network around an entire planet, and it made me appreciate the scale of this game. Everything is just within your reach if your ambitious, but far enough away for you to be challenged.

140991372.review:
What a gem this game is, goodness I wish more people knew about it. 

There is something so immensely satisfying with how tactile everything is. Everything sorta clicks and pops together, whether it's plugging in the power cord to a something, or attaching a module to a platform. Even inventory kinda works similar to this with items you find out in the wild. It's something you have to see for yourself, but it's just so damn satisfying. 

The art design... what can I say.... It's some of the finest work I've ever seen in gaming. Simple yet, jaw droppingly gorgeous. I gotta give homage to the original art designer Paul Pepera, may he rest in peace and his beautiful imagination be immortalized within this game. 

This game has something for everyone really. From exploring and navigating dangerous environments. to building your base and maintaining your resources. Building and driving wild exocraft, or shooting off into the stars to explore a new planet. 

I could ramble on and on about the game but honestly you should see it for yourself. Do it now! Play the game!!

29191012.review:
[h1] Yes Man's Sky [/h1]

I don't normally write reviews for games, but frankly ASTRONEER caught me off guard in a way i wasn't expecting.

I've played survival games up the arse, and some i've stuck with, some i've refunded, some i played for a bit and then never touched again, but with ASTRONEER i was instantly in love with the way it presented itself, bugs and all.

Sure, the game is nowhere near complete - once you've researched every blueprint and built everything there isn't anything to do, but this is obviously still to come, and i get the feeling that the future of this game is going to be especially bright.

I've poured hours into straight sessions just listening to the bubbling of materials into my  backpack and the lovely bloopy soundtrack that really does add a level of polish to the game.

The visuals are wonderful too, with a polygonal/minimalist design that works superbly. You have your more graphically intensive examples of games like this, but frankly it doesn't need it and delivers itself brilliantly.

The game does have its bugs like dropping items through floors, some of which i know were addressed in a recent patch, as well as some of the vehicle bay physics being slightly off once the spaceship gets involved... but these are easy fixes that will no doubt be dealt with swiftly through the Early Access phase (hopefully!)

If you want a nice, relaxing but slightly cerebral survival game that could basically be described as "Yes Man's Sky" then this game is for you. If that description repulses you to your core, i understand - but maybe try it anyway!

28666171.review:
"Minecraft meets Space Engineers"


So I've tested this game in Early/Access for a couple of hours, alone and with friends, and I must say it's a blast! With some spoilers.

Playing COOP tends to be super fun in the early minutes of the game, though for many it's getting a mess after a couple of hours. Not because players mined all the planets, but because the game can become very buggy. And we've experienced that in many sessions.

Client crashes, but especially the base and terrain desync makes it really annoying and sometimes impossible to play together, since it occurs that you can't help building stuff and are always at high risk to fall into weird terrain holes to die once the desync happened. Reconnecting doesn't help either, only starting a complete new game from scratch.

In SP, everything seems to work so much better.


ASTRONEER cons:
- annoying desyncs in COOP
- currently no dedicated server support
- not much content due to e/a; after 10 hour playtime you've probably seen everything of the current state.

ASTRONEER pros:
+ great exploration and mining game, especially in COOP
+ simple, but great graphic appearance
+ very interesting tool and economy systems


ASTRONEER is definitely good shit! But it needs to get rid of the major bugs and also needs a lot more content to be enjoyable long-term. I'm really looking forward to the full version of this game!

It’s broad to cover many circumstances that could be problematic and require forthrightness, especially since the passing of stronger privacy law in the EU. Astroneer does not contain any advertisements, and collects only telemetry required to enable in-game achievements and monitor game stability.

If anyone wishes not to play Astroneer because of the content of the EULA, we understand and respect your decision. The EULA is what it is to enable us to make all the games we might wish to make, in all regions, abiding by all applicable law.
